column4: Definition

column3: Application Development Software > Business Rules Management
column4: Business Rules Management (BRM) is a software tool used to create, maintain, and govern business rules within an organization. By centralizing and automating rule management, organizations can improve decision-making, enforce compliance, optimize workflows, and automate complex decision-making processes.

column3: Application Development Software > Development Languages, Environment and Tools
column4: Development Languages, Environment, and Tools are used to create and maintain software applications. Development Languages are used to write computer programs. Development Environments provide tools and features that help developers write, test, and debug code efficiently. Development Tools are specialized applications that assist in the development process, such as version control systems, debuggers, and testing frameworks.

column3: Application Development Software > Modeling and Simulation Tools
column4: Modeling and Simulation Tools are software applications used to create virtual models of real-world systems. These tools enable the analysis and prediction of system behavior under various conditions by simulating complex scenarios, so that organizations can identify potential problems, optimize processes, and make informed decisions.

Software Components are self-contained units of software with well-defined interfaces that developers can reuse across different applications. By breaking down complex systems into smaller components, developers can improve maintainability, scalability, and faster software development.

column3: Application Life Cycle Management > Software Change, Configuration, and Process Management
column4: Software Change, Configuration, and Process Management (SCCM) is the management of changes to software systems. It includes identifying, assessing, approving, planning, implementing, and verifying software changes that minimize risks, and maintain the integrity of software systems.

column3: Application Life Cycle Management > Automated Testing and Quality Management
column4: Automated Testing and Quality Management is a suite of tools designed to automate software testing and improvement. These tools optimize the creation, execution, and analysis of test cases by automating repetitive tasks to increase efficiency, accuracy, and test coverage.

Application Middleware is software that facilitates communication and data exchange between different applications and systems. By acting as a bridge between disparate systems, it enables integration and interoperability across services like messaging, transaction processing, and security, enhancing application scalability, reliability, and performance.

Business-to-Business Middleware (B2B Middleware) is software that facilitates communication and data exchange between business applications and systems. It helps organizations integrate their systems, regardless of the underlying technologies, enabling seamless data transfer and interoperability.

Event-Driven Middleware is a software layer that enables applications to communicate and react to events in real-time. This middleware is often used in distributed systems, allowing asynchronous communication where systems can send and receive messages without blocking each other, facilitating efficient and scalable event-driven architectures.

Integration Middleware is a software layer that connects different systems and applications, enabling data sharing and interoperability. It provides a standardized way for businesses to integrate their systems (regardless of the underlying technologies), break down silos, improve data consistency, and enhance overall business efficiency.

column3: Business Process Management > Process Modelling and Design
column4: Process Modeling and Design are software tools used to represent and analyze business processes through diagrams, flowcharts, and other visualizations to make them easier to understand, analyze, and optimize. Organizations use these tools to identify bottlenecks, improve efficiency, and make data-driven decisions to streamline operations.

Process simulation software is an application used to model and analyze complex systems, optimize processes, and predict outcomes. Use cases vary by industry; however, the overall objective is to help organizations make data-driven decisions to improve efficiency and workflows, reduce costs and downtime, and enhance overall performance.

Database Development software is used to design, create, and manage databases. These tools provide features for data modeling, query building, and database administration, allowing organizations to manage and analyze large amounts of data and ensure data integrity and accessibility.

Database Management software (DBMS) is an application that helps organizations create, define, manipulate, and manage databases. It provides a structured way to store, organize, and retrieve large amounts of data efficiently. DBMS features include data definition, data manipulation, data query, and data security.

Managed File Transfer software manages the secure transfer of files from one computer to another through a network. The file transfer can be from one organization to another or within an organization, across datacenters or systems.

Data Management software is a suite of tools designed to organize, store, and manage an organization's data. It centralizes data, helping businesses collect, clean, integrate, and analyze it to gain insights.

Data Quality software is a set of tools designed to identify, correct, and prevent data errors and inconsistencies. It helps organizations analyze data accuracy, completeness, and conformity to business rules to improve data quality and reduce the risk of errors and fraud.

column3: Information Management > Data Integration and Access Software
column4: Data Integration and Access software consolidates data from various sources into a single, unified view. It extracts, transforms, and loads data into a target system, ensuring consistency and accessibility.

Linux is a family of open-source Unix-like operating systems based on the Linux kernel. Linux is characterized by its flexibility, security, and community-driven development and can power a variety of devices, ranging from servers and supercomputers to smartphones and embedded systems.

Unix is a line of multitasking, multi-user computer operating systems characterized by stability, security, and portability. It has influenced many modern operating systems, including Linux and macOS. Unix is often used in servers, workstations, and supercomputers.
Windows is an operating system developed by Microsoft. It provides a user-friendly graphical interface for interacting with a wide range of devices, from personal computers to servers.

A mainframe is a large, powerful computer system designed to process massive amounts of data and handle multiple tasks simultaneously. Mainframes are known for reliability and security, making them ideal for critical applications like financial transactions and large-scale data processing.

Mac OS X (now known as macOS) is an operating system developed and marketed by Apple. It is the primary operating system for Apple's Mac computers, characterized by a user-friendly interface, stability, and security features.

Other Operating Systems (OSs) are specialized software platforms designed to meet specific computing needs. Each OS is tailored to cater to specific computing requirements and user preferences, offering unique features, performance characteristics, and user experiences.

Network Management software monitors, configures, and troubleshoots network devices and systems. It provides a centralized interface for managing network infrastructure, ensuring optimal performance, security, and reliability.

Configuration Management software is used to manage and control changes to software and systems. It helps track versions, automate tasks, and ensure consistency across different environments, reducing errors and improving efficiency.

IT Service Desk software is a tool used for managing and resolving IT issues and requests. It provides a centralized platform for IT teams to efficiently manage incidents, problems, and service requests, improving overall IT service delivery.

IT Asset Management (ITAM) software is a tool that is used to track and manage IT assets throughout their lifecycle. It provides a centralized repository of data about hardware, software, and licenses, which helps businesses improve IT efficiency, optimize asset utilization, and meet compliance requirements.

Job scheduling software automates the execution of tasks or processes, freeing up system resources and improving operational efficiency. It allows users to define, schedule, and monitor the execution of jobs based on specific criteria like time, dependencies, or events. By optimizing resource utilization and ensuring timely task completion, job scheduling software helps organizations streamline their workflows and enhance productivity.

Output Management Systems (OMS) software streamlines the workflow of generating, managing, and delivering documents within an organization. It automates tasks like document creation, formatting, routing, and distribution by centralizing control over document workflows, print processes, and delivery across channels.

Identity and Access Management (IAM) is a security framework that manages digital identities and controls access to resources. It involves processes like user authentication, authorization, and single sign-on. IAM ensures that only authorized individuals can access sensitive information and systems, protecting against unauthorized access and data breaches.

Information and Threat Management applications are software that proactively identify, assess and mitigate security risks. These applications help organizations monitor network traffic, detect anomalies, and respond to threats in real-time to help protect sensitive information and systems from spam, viruses, intrusions, and cyberattacks. Information and Threat Management includes enterprise/network firewalls, antivirus software, antispyware, antispam, and web filtering.

Vulnerability Management software are applications that identify, interpret, report, and improve the security vulnerabilities in systems and applications. They scan for weaknesses, prioritize risks, and provide recommendations for remediation. By effectively managing vulnerabilities, organizations can reduce the risk of cyberattacks and protect sensitive data. Features include: security policy management, configuration assessment, vulnerability assessment, remediation, patch management, security logs management, and single point of control for managing security systems.

column3: Storage Management > Data Archiving, Back-Up and Recovery
column4: Data Archiving, Back-Up, and Recovery software is designed to protect and restore data. It encompasses creating copies of data, storing it securely, and mechanisms for recovering data in case of loss or corruption, helping organizations to minimize the impact of data loss incidents and ensure business continuity.

Storage Device Management software manages and monitors storage devices such as hard drives, SSDs, and network storage systems. It includes features for storage provisioning, capacity planning, performance optimization, and data migration ensuring an organization's data availability, reliability, and performance.

Storage Infrastructure Software manages and optimizes storage infrastructure. Features include storage provisioning, capacity planning, performance optimization, and data migration, helping organizations manage storage resources and ensure data availability, reliability, and performance.

Storage Replication Software is used to create and maintain copies of data across multiple storage locations, ensuring data redundancy and disaster recovery. This software helps organizations maintain business continuity by providing access to data even in the event of hardware failures or natural disasters.
Virtual Desktops are software-based desktop environments that can be accessed remotely. They allow users to work from any device with an internet connection.

Server Management is a tool for managing and monitoring servers. It automates tasks like system updates, security patches, and performance optimization. It helps maintain server health, security, and performance, reducing manual efforts and minimizing downtime.

Server Infrastructure is the hardware and software that act as the foundation of a computing environment. It includes servers, storage devices, networking equipment, and operating systems, providing the resources needed to run applications and services.
Business Risk & Compliance software is used by an organization to measure the effectiveness of their Governance, Risk and Compliance strategies with regards to the regulatory requirements.
Business intelligence and analytics tools are used to retrieve, analyze, transform and report data for business intelligence.

Team Collaboration Applications are digital platforms that provide a centralized hub for communication, project management, file sharing, and real-time collaboration. These applications streamline workflows, foster communication, and facilitate remote work.
Email is a digital communication software for sending and receiving messages electronically.

Conferencing applications are software that enables real-time communication and collaboration between individuals or groups. They offer features like video conferencing, screen sharing, and instant messaging, facilitating remote meetings, presentations, and discussions.

column3: Collaboration > File Synchronization and Sharing Software
column4: File Synchronization and Sharing Software is designed to facilitate seamless collaboration and data accessibility across diverse devices and platforms. It automatically synchronizes files, ensuring consistency and up-to-date versions across multiple locations.

Enterprise Mobility Management (EMM) is software that enables organizations to manage and secure mobile devices within the corporate environment. It allows businesses to maintain centralized control over device deployment, configuration, monitoring, and security, to ensure data protection, compliance, and productivity.

Commerce Application is used by the enterprises for the management of their e-commerce activities. This software provide support for Catalog Management, E-Merchandising, Payment Gateway, Subscription Management, Product Information Management and Shopping Cart.

column3: Content Management and Creation > Authoring and Publishing Software
column4: Authoring and Publishing Software is a suite of tools used to create, edit, and distribute content. It provides a platform for writing, formatting, and designing documents, presentations, and other digital media.

column3: Content Management and Creation > Content Analytics, and Discovery Software
column4: Content Analytics and Discovery Software is a tool for analyzing and interpreting data related to digital content performance. It tracks views, engagement, and sharing metrics to provide insights into audience preferences and content effectiveness.

column3: Content Management and Creation > Content Management
column4: Content Management Software (CMS) is a centralized platform for storing, organizing, and editing digital content. It helps businesses manage their websites, blogs, and other digital assets, ensuring consistent branding and timely updates.

Engineering Applications software is used for the management of specific activities related to ideas generation and management, concept development and the handoff of a design to execution. Typical Engineering applications include CAD, CAM and BIM software’s.
Enterprise Asset Management software is used for the management of asset and maintenance, repair, and overhaul (MRO) operations of an organization.

Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) software is a comprehensive suite of integrated applications designed to manage an organization's core business processes. It centralizes, automates, and optimizes processes and data across various resources including people, finances, capital, materials, and facilities resulting in comprehensive and consolidated business analysis, forecasting, and reporting for executive decision makers. Typical ERP systems include ERP planning, financial management, HCM, supply chain, CRM, manufacturing PLC, distribution, sourcing and procurement and project and portfolio management.

column3: Enterprise Resource Planning Applications > Financial Applications
column4: Financial Applications are used for the management of accounting and financial functions. Typical Financial Applications includes Accounting software’s, corporate performance management (SCPM) solutions.

column3: Enterprise Resource Planning Applications > Human Capital Management
column4: Human Capital Management applications are used for the management of people.  These applications support Personnel administration, Payroll, Workforce planning, Time and expense management, Learning, Recruitment, Onboarding, etc. functions of an enterprise.

column3: Enterprise Resource Planning Applications > Supply Chain Management Applications
column4: Supply chain management applications supports the flow of product from production to the final customer. Functions supported include Logistics, Production Planning and Inventory Management, etc.

column3: Enterprise Resource Planning Applications > Customer Relationship Management Applications
column4: Customer Relationship Management Applications are used for the management of interaction with providers and customers. Functions supported include Customer Service, Contact Center.

column3: Enterprise Resource Planning Applications > Manufacturing Product Life Cycle Management
column4: Manufacturing Product Life Cycle Management applications supports the management of entire lifecycle of a product from inception, through engineering, design and manufacturing to disposal of product. Functions supported include Services Operations Management, Material requirement planning, Bills of Material (BOM), manufacturing process planning and simulation, manufacturing execution (MES) and other back office functions of a manufacturing enterprise.

column3: Enterprise Resource Planning Applications > Distribution Management
column4: Distribution management applications are used to plan and deploy resources across different locations of an enterprise. Distribution management software’s collect, organize, display and analyze the distribution data and operations. Distribution management applications can be are integrated with other software’s like GIS, CRM for a wider view of distribution operations.

column3: Enterprise Resource Planning Applications > Sourcing and Procurement
column4: Sourcing and Procurement automates business process related to purchasing material. Functions supported include supplier selection, supplier performance analysis, eProcurement, Contract management, Spending analysis, Strategic sourcing, Contract management, tracking, enforcement, etc.

column3: Enterprise Resource Planning Applications > Project and Portfolio Management
column4: Project and Portfolio Management are used for managing a project and it supports the various stages of the project management. Project management functions supported include project initiation, project planning/scheduling, resource allocation, monitoring, and measuring of activities and resources.

Industry Specific Applications software perform supports tasks or functions which are specific to an industry. The software cannot be used by a different industry. For example a Core banking application can only be used by banking industry and cannot be used by another industry.
The software is used to produce information, such as documents, presentations, worksheets, databases, charts, graphs, digital paintings, electronic music and digital video.
Performance Management & Analytic Applications software is used to measure, analyze, and optimize performance management processes.
Sales Management software’s supports all the stages in a sales process. Typical activities supported include Account/contact management, sales lead tracking, list management, sales forecasting, etc.

Marketing Management software’s supports all stages in marketing process. Typical activities supported include Ad management, campaign management, database marketing, brand management, direct marketing, digital marketing, web advertising, Media and analyst relations, marketing resource management, etc.

Spatial Information Management software (also called as Geographic information systems (GIS)) is designed to capture, store, map, manipulate, manage, analyze and display the Geographical or spatial data.

A desktop computer is a personal computer designed for regular use at a single location and to fit on top of or near a typical office desk to accommodate size and power requirements. The most common configuration includes a processor unit that houses the power supply, motherboard, memory, and disk storage, along with a display monitor and keyboard and mouse input devices.

A handheld computing device is a small, portable computer that you can hold in your hand and is designed for easy use and mobility. These devices often have a touchscreen interface and run on a mobile operating system. Examples include tablets, martphones, and PDAs.

A laptop/notebook computer, is a small, portable personal computer with a clamshell form factor and powered with a rechargeable battery or AC power adaptor. It is typically equipped with a thin LCD or LED computer screen mounted on the inside of the upper lid of the clamshell and an alphanumeric keyboard on the inside of the lower lid.

Servers are computers that provide services to other computers on a network. A server can be a physical machine or a virtual machine running on a physical server. Servers can perform various functions, including file serving, print serving, application serving, database serving, web serving and email serving.

Thin clients are lightweight devices with limited processing power and storage that rely on a central server to perform most of their computational tasks. These devices are characterized by minimal hardware, high network dependency, and use of remote desktop protocols (such as RDP or VNC) to connect to a server and access its resources.

Workstations are high-performance computers that require significant processing power, memory, and storage. They are often used in fields such as engineering, design, scientific research, and video editing.

Unclassified computing devices are any other type of electronic device capable of performing calculations and processing data. They can receive information, manipulate or analyze data, display or deliver results, and store data.
A display device is an electronic device that presents images, text, or other data on a screen.
Scanning and imaging peripherals are devices used to capture and convert visual information into a digital format.
A print device is a peripheral that accepts text and graphic output from a computer and transfers the information to paper to produce a physical version of an electronic document.
A sound/audio device is a hardware component capable of producing, recording, or reproducing sound. Examples include speakers, microphones, headphones, and audio interfaces.
A peripheral device is a hardware component that is external to a computer system used to input data, output information, or store data.
Components are uniquely identifiable parts of a computing device. Many components make up a single computing device.
Bridges are devices that connect networks together, extending the reach of a network and allowing communication between devices on different networks.

Concentrators are devices that combine multiple data streams into a single stream for transmission over a single channel. Their purpose is to reduce the number of cables required and improve network efficiency.

Gateways are devices that interconnect networks with different network protocol technologies by performing the required protocol conversions. The activities of a gateway are more complex than that of the router or switch because it communicates using more than one protocol.
A private switch is a type of network switch used within a private network that provides switching capabilities for internal communication and data transfer between devices within the network.

A modem is a device that modulates and demodulates data signals, allowing communication over a physical medium such as a telephone line or cable connection. It is primarily used to connect computers to the internet.
Routers are network devices that forward data packets between networks, connect multiple networks together, and route traffic efficiently.

column3: Customer Premise Equipment > Wireless Access Points
column4: Wireless access points (WAPs) are devices that provide wireless network connectivity. They transmit and receive data signals, allowing digital devices to connect to the internet wirelessly.

column3: Customer Premise Equipment > Voice / Multimedia Device > Mobile
column4: Mobile devices are portable and generally wireless electronic devices such as smartphones, tablets, and laptops.

column3: Customer Premise Equipment > Voice / Multimedia Device > Fixed
column4: Fixed multimedia/voice devices are devices that are designed to be used in a stationary location. Examples include landline phones, desktop computers, and home theater systems.
Unclassified refers to technology that is waiting to be assigned by HG or falls outside the standard taxonomy classifications.

column3: Telecommunication Equipment > Public Switching Equipment > Analogue
column4: Analogue public switching equipment is a type of telecommunications equipment that uses continuously varying physical quantities (such as voltage or sound waves) to connect telephone lines together.

column3: Telecommunication Equipment > Public Switching Equipment > Digital
column4: Digital public switching equipment is a type of telecommunications equipment used to connect telephone lines. It uses digital technology to represent and transmit data, allowing for higher-quality, efficiency, and versatile communication.
Radio transmission equipment is hardware used to transmit and receive radio waves. Examples include components such as transmitters, receivers, antennas, and modulation/demodulation circuits.
Fixed transmission equipment is hardware designed for stationary use, such as infrastructure like telecommunications networks.
Satellite transmission equipment is hardware used to transmit and receive data signals via satellites orbiting the Earth. It includes satellite dishes, antennas, modems, and amplifiers.

column3: Security Appliances > Content Filtering and Antispam Appliances
column4: Content filtering and antispam appliances are devices that examine network traffic to identify and block harmful or unwanted content, such as malware, viruses, and spam.

column3: Security Appliances > Encryption and SSL Accelerators
column4: Encryption and SSL Accelerators are security measures used to protect sensitive information. Encryption refers to the conversion of data into code, making it unreadable. SSL (Secure Socket Layer) Accelerators are hardware devices designed to offload the computationally intensive tasks of SSL/TLS encryption and decryption from the server's CPU.

A firewall appliance is a hardware device that protects networks from unauthorized access, prevents cyberattacks, and safeguards data. It monitors incoming and outgoing network traffic, filters out malicious activity, and enforces security policies.

Physical Security Devices are security hardware used to monitor and control access to systems and locations. Examples include card readers, biometric scanners, surveillance cameras, and alarm systems which are designed to safeguard property and personnel.

High end servers are generally used in centralized computing environments and are located within the data center and ranges from few terabytes to hundreds of terabytes. These servers ensure higher system availability via mirroring of cache and disk and offer higher level of data protection.

Mid-range servers are used in distributed computing environments and offers RAID protection and replication. This commodity hardware is best suited for discrete applications and offers relatively lower system availability compared to high end servers.
Direct attached storage devices are directly attached to the computer or a server. For ex- Internal hard drive.
Network attached storage devices are connected to computers or servers on a network and provide additional storage space for the computers or servers.
Storage area network is a high speed network of storage devices connected to the servers. SAN provides block level data storage.
Tape systems are storage devices that read and write data on a magnetic tape. These storage devices are used for offline, backup or archival data storage.
Storage systems which are not classified as Direct attached storage, NAS, SAN or tap systems.

column3: Application Development and Maintenance > One-time Activity
column4: Application Development and Maintenance (ADM) encompasses the entire lifecycle of software applications, from inception to ongoing customer support. It includes developing custom solutions to solve a specific business need, modifying existing applications to adapt to evolving requirements, and improving applications to correct errors and ensure optimal performance and security through proactive maintenance.

Application Hosting is the storage, running, and management of applications on remote servers owned either by the enterprise or a service provider. This service provides the necessary infrastructure, including hardware, software, and network connectivity, to ensure applications are accessible and functional including support, maintenance, guaranteed uptime, backups, performance tuning, and updates.

Application Management is the day-to-day management, support, planning, and maintenance of custom or packaged software applications licensed by the customer.  It involves activities like performance monitoring, incident management, change management, availability, and security.

A service providers responsibilities include the validation and testing of new, existing or modified application(s). Testing ensures that the software application meets the business and technical requirements of the client. The service provider will test the application for security, operability and durability.

Providing services for the continued management, operation, and availability of an organization’s IT infrastructure, consisting of hardware; software and network resources. The infrastructure is remotely managed and the performance is measured against agreed service level agreements.

A service provider will host in its own data centers, a customer’s own assets or rent to a customer, servers, mainframes, storage, and network devices, providing associated disaster recovery; network; and security services.

Services provided include the validation of the suitability; availability and performance of a client’s existing or newly deployed IT infrastructure to meet the stated business and technical requirements of the client. Typically services are contracted where clients look to deploy changes such as data center consolidation; virtualization and technology upgrades.

A service provider acquires and manages a client’s physical data center(s) and provides the day-to-day running of servers; mainframes; networks and storage. The service provider also optimizes and enhances the service delivery and maintains the agreed levels of service.
The service provider is responsible for the day-to-day monitoring; operations; availability; maintenance and support of the client’s servers.

The service provider is responsible for the maintenance; capacity planning; deployment; backup; archive and retrieval, and management of offline and online storage systems and networks. Services may be delivered on-site in customer data centers, or through a service provider or third-party remotely hosted site.

column3: Business Continuity / Disaster Recovery > Ongoing Activity
column4: Providing services to ensure continued operations in the aftermath of a catastrophic natural disaster or national emergency. Services may include restoring servers or mainframes with backups, re-establishing connectivity or provisioning networks to meet immediate business needs.
The installation and integration of printers; storage devices; servers; desktops; workstations and mainframes.

The services provider will rent out space in its data center in which customers can install their servers and networking equipment. The services provider will also provide the power, bandwidth, IP address and cooling systems that the customer will require in order to successfully deploy and run their equipment’s.

Services provided include the planning; specification; and design of network; architectures and roadmaps/plans. Services are similar to IT consulting but incorporates services with respect to the development of Network/LAN/WAN.

The Service provider is responsible for the planning and development of voice; mobile and data networks. Services to be provided include installation; configuration; Network related software development; testing; staging; project management and security implementation activities. Network technologies comprise: computer network infrastructure equipment; data communications equipment; remote access equipment; LAN/WAN switches and routers; network interface cards and software-defined network infrastructure.

The Service provider is responsible for the installation and day-to-day management of network tools as well as the integration and management of private Wide-Area Networks (WAN) and Local Area Networks (LAN). The service provider will also assist with fault isolation and resolution which will optimize the efficiency of networks and avoid downtime. The service provider also installs and configures the system; manages network software upgrades; hardware upgrades and user management on the network.

Services provided include the deployment of network hardware infrastructure like small cells deployments, Router deployments, LAN/WAN Switches, Gateways. Services provided lack the integration, management and maintenance of network.

The Service desk provider acts as a central point of contact for reporting incidents and service requests; managing the escalation and resolution processes. The service desk provider is the single point of contact for all service provider; end-user and IT operations incidents. A service desk provider can also coordinate change management, problem management, configuration management, release and continuity management activities.

The Service provider is responsible for the procurement; deployment; remote management and break/fix maintenance of IT assets (hardware and software); deskside support and network services. The service provider will provide support for desktop PCs and laptops as well as manage mobile devices such as tablets and smartphone to provide access to enterprise applications; network and data.
The Service provider acts as a first level support channel for the service desk and refers end-users enquiries to the relevant technical staff.

Services provided include the design; development; management and continuous operation of the client’s IT security systems. Services providers also manage all areas of IT security, including firewalls; content filtering; intrusion/threat detection; ID and access management; biometrics; and threat mitigation.

Services provided include migration of workload to new hardware systems; software systems and data centers. Services provider will also develop technical training programs for the client’s staff; provide project/program evaluation, and translation services.

The services provider will be responsible for the management of a client’s document output. The services provided include needs assessment, replacement of hardware (such as printers, fax machines, copiers and multifunction devices), replacement of parts and supplies needed to operate the new and/or existing hardware and provision of associated services.
Services provided include the creation, aggregation, management, personalization, and distribution of static and dynamic information via the Web and other networks.
Services provided include the planning; specification and design of systems and processes for the sole purpose of automating people dependent tasks.
Services provided include assisting client in developing business strategy; improving processes; business process re-engineering; capacity planning; and change management services.
Services provided include the planning; specification and design of systems; architectures; and infrastructures.

Services provided typically focus on supporting a client through their outsourcing strategy, vendor selection and negotiation, vendor and process transition, contract specification. Services may extend to ongoing vendor and contract performance management.
Services provided include linking together different computing systems and software applications physically or functionally, to act as a coordinated whole.
Analyzing client business data to help the client make better decisions. Services typically include the production of reports and client dashboards.

column3: Customer Relationship Management (CRM) BPO > Ongoing Activity
column4: Customer Relationship Management (CRM) BPO is the delegation of customer-handling functions to a third-party provider. Activities include single or multi-channel support (inquiries across phone, email, chat, text, and social media), inbound and outbound customer contact services, IVR and call routing, webchat, and agent voice communications.

column3: Finance and Accounting (F&A) BPO > Ongoing Activity
column4: Services provided to support operations for the transactional and financial support functions of a client. Typical F&A BPO process outsourcing includes accounts payable and receivable; accounts reconciliation and reporting; purchase order processing and general ledger.

Services provided to support the operation of HR shared services; Services include: recruitment; payroll; benefits administration; relocation and assignment services; and talent management/ workforce development .

The Service provider will be responsible for the sourcing and supply chain management activities for a client. The service provider will provide direct procurement services to manage all or part of the process for the procurement of goods and services that are core (Go into the manufacturer of goods or services) and non core (for internal use) to an end user clients activities.

Services provided are specific to the industry of the client such as patient administration; clinical data management for healthcare providers; insurance claims and transaction processing for insurance providers.
Services provided include research and development; financial consultancy and services; business and technical analysis; business research; copy and content development.

Services provided to an organization obtaining legal support services from an outside law firm or legal support company. Services provided include agency work; document review; legal research; drafting of pleadings and briefs and patent services.

Providing technology and service solutions to automate processes and tasks ‘within an existing application environment’. Examples include the automation of business processes, IT support processes, workflow processes, remote infrastructure and back-office work.

The services provider will be responsible for the management of business process involving repetitive activities to process large volumes of similar information. Examples: claims processing (healthcare and insurance), check processing, consumer payment processing, payroll processing and electronic data processing.

Provision of business process outsourcing (BPO) services sourced over the cloud. The services are highly standardized and automated and could be provided as SaaS, IaaS and Paas. Services are provided under Consumption based or subscription based pricing models.
The provision of virtual desktop infrastructure (VDI) from a public cloud, private cloud or a service provider’s data centers. Services are provided under a pay-per-use pricing model.

The provision of compute resources complemented by storage resources; network resources owned and hosted by the service provider. These resources are virtualized. The services provider may deliver the managed services from its own datacenter(s) or may provide services around a third-party public cloud (such as Microsoft Azure; Rackspace Cloud or Amazon Web Services).

The provision of cloud platform to develop, deploy, run, manage, and maintain applications, APIs or data assets. The services provider may deliver the managed services from its own datacenter(s) or may provide services around a third-party public cloud (such as Amazon Web Services, Rackspace Cloud or Microsoft Azure).

The provision of software over a cloud platform where the software is licensed on a subscription basis and managed by the service provider. Service providers may also deliver their own / third-party software (under license) and services from their own / third-party data centers as SaaS. Services provided will include customization; migration and on-boarding services.

column3: Service integration and Management (SIAM) > Ongoing Activity
column4: In a multisource IT outsourcing environment a SIAM provider will integrate interdependent services from various external and internal service providers into end-to-end services to meet the business requirements of a customer. The SIAM provider governs these other services providers. SIAM providers do not own the contracts with other service providers, these remain owned by the customer.

Strategy and transformation consulting services, supporting senior business stakeholders such as CEOs; COOs; Chief marketing officers (CMOs) and other business leaders, to leverage digital technologies to enable innovation within their business and operating models. Specific capabilities include consulting services for digital strategy and transformation, digital operations, and digital customer experience.

IT and process management services required by a company to acquire, provision and support smartphones, tablets and ruggedized field force devices with integrated cellular and/or wireless connectivity.

column3: Social collaboration/Enterprise social networking/Enterprise 2.0 > Ongoing Activity
column4: Modifications to corporate intranets (referred to as social intranets) and other software platforms used by large companies to support communication and collaboration processes

column3: Unified Communications and Collaboration > Ongoing Activity
column4: Services provided to integrate tools, process and people to achieve effective communications, agility and operational efficiency within an organization. Systems might include: Enterprise content management (ECM); e-mail and calendaring; Web conferencing; shared work spaces/team collaboration; Instant Messaging; e-learning suites; information access with search; and ECM systems.
Blockchain is a digital ledger in which transactions are recorded chronologically and publicly. The transactions could be made in bitcoin or any other cryptocurrency.

column3: Smart Factory / Industry 4.0 (Manufacturing Application) > One-Time Activity
column4: Use of Internet of Things and embedded technology to communicate with IT systems to streamline the manufacturing process.

column3: Smart Transportation / Car IT (Transportation Application) > One-Time Activity
column4: Use of Internet of Things and embedded technology to communicate with IT systems in a car and a contract station to drive a vehicle or monitor vehicle.

column3: Smart Energy (Energy Management Application) > One-Time Activity
column4: Use of Internet of Things and embedded technology to communicate with IT systems and to monitor and maintain production and distribution of electricity.

column3: Smart Health (Medical and healthcare application) > One-Time Activity
column4: Use of Internet of Things and embedded technology to communicate with IT systems and to monitor and maintain the health of patients.

column3: Industry Specific IoT Applications > One-Time Activity
column4: Services provided are specific to an industry. Use of Internet of Things and embedded technology to communicate with IT systems to streamline the process within a company.

Includes the provision of local and long-distance services related to voice (calling charges; line rental/subscription and connection fees are included in this category); enhanced voice services; data and fax transmission over the circuit-switched PSTN; Voice over IP (Excludes wholesale or carrier-to-carrier revenue and services).

The provision of dedicated/private line, packet and circuit-switched access services (for example, frame relay, asynchronous transfer mode, IP, Integrated Services Digital Network, DSL, multichannel multipoint distribution service [MMDS] and satellite) services. All types of transmissions — non voice data, image, video, fax, interactive services and even voice can be carried by these services regardless of whether the source format is analog or digital.

Provision of mobile telephone calls and mobile data usage (Short Message Service [SMS] and mobile data access) through portable or mobile terminals that communicate through ground based wireless cell towers.
Telephone and data services provided through portable or mobile terminals that communicate via telecommunications satellites.
Unclassified technology is either not yet categorized or falls outside of the standard technology categories.
